name: The Rise of Golf
description: Golf has evolved from a traditional country-club pastime into a modern lifestyle movement. A new generation of players — fueled by social media, fashion, and wellness culture — is redefining what the sport represents. It’s no longer about exclusivity or handicap; it’s about expression, balance, and identity. Golf has become a hybrid between mindfulness and competition — a way to connect, reflect, and perform. The game’s revival has turned courses, simulators, and even practice ranges into social playgrounds for a creative, ambitious generation that values focus, style, and shared experiences.
coreDrivers: Several key forces are driving the rise of golf as a cultural movement. The democratization of access has lowered barriers to entry, with younger and more diverse players discovering golf through public courses, simulator lounges, and affordable gear. Social media has transformed the sport’s aesthetic — golf swings, outfits, and even course moments have become cinematic, viral expressions of personal style. Post-pandemic, golf also capitalized on the outdoor revival, offering safe socialization and a mindful break from digital overload. Meanwhile, fashion crossovers from brands like Malbon, Eastside Golf, and Devereux have fused sport with streetwear, while new tech innovations — launch monitors, AR swing analyzers, and simulator software — have made the game more data-driven and accessible than ever.
keyBehaviors: Evidence of this trend appears across culture. Off-course experiences like Topgolf, Drive Shack, and Five Iron Golf are booming, making golf part of nightlife and casual recreation. Golf fashion is crossing into daily wear, with minimalist polos, collared knits, and clean silhouettes showing up far beyond the fairway. Content creators like Good Good, Rick Shiels, and Bob Does Sports are redefining golf entertainment, blending humor, expertise, and authenticity. Younger players now see premium clubs as identity statements — a reflection of personal discipline and taste. Courses themselves are evolving too, allowing faster play formats, music-friendly rounds, and community-driven experiences that align with a more modern pace of life.
emotionalCulturalMeaning: Culturally, golf represents balance, authenticity, and mastery. It’s a counter-movement to chaos — a place where calm precision meets performance. For many, it’s a way to find flow and focus, a form of mindfulness that doesn’t feel passive. Golf satisfies a generational desire to slow down while still improving, connecting progress with presence. Emotionally, it’s tied to self-expression, ritual, and belonging — a community built on shared pursuit rather than status.
whoIsLeading: This trend is being led by a blend of cultural brands, digital creators, and modern athletes. Lifestyle-driven golf brands like Malbon Golf, Eastside Golf, and Devereux have turned the game into a fashion ecosystem, while legacy brands like Nike Golf and TaylorMade are repositioning themselves to appeal to new audiences. Influential media voices such as Good Good, Rick Shiels, and Barstool’s Fore Play are shaping online conversation, making golf content entertaining and relatable. Celebrities and athletes outside the golf world — including Steph Curry, Michelle Wie, and Tyler, The Creator — have further blurred the lines between performance, culture, and creativity.
whoIsFollowing: The followers of this trend are largely Millennial and Gen Z professionals between 25 and 45 who crave purpose-driven leisure. They’re digital natives, entrepreneurial, and wellness-conscious — drawn to golf as a form of discipline, networking, and creative recreation. They’re not necessarily country-club members; they’re hybrid professionals who mix city life with outdoor pursuits. This group values authenticity, community, and craftsmanship, viewing golf not just as a game but as a form of identity and personal development.
opportunityForBrands: Brands have an opportunity to engage this movement by reframing golf as a lifestyle, not just a sport. Products can be designed and marketed as both functional and fashionable, bridging on-course performance with off-course aesthetics. Campaigns should celebrate inclusivity, style, and the modern rituals of play, highlighting the culture surrounding golf rather than only the technical details. Digital storytelling that leans into creators, data, and design can help brands feel embedded within this new wave, rather than observers of it. This trend invites brands to merge athleticism and culture — performance meets personality.
risksMissteps: The biggest risk for brands engaging this trend is inauthenticity. Leaning too heavily on stereotypes of “old golf” — elitism, exclusivity, or overt tradition — immediately alienates the new audience. Over-simplifying the narrative to “young people discovering golf” also misses the nuance; this generation already owns the movement. Brands must show that they belong in this evolving culture through collaboration, genuine participation, and thoughtful storytelling, not opportunistic marketing.
exampleInAction: Imagine a TaylorMade campaign titled “Play the Shift.” The creative concept highlights golfers from design, tech, and creative industries who see golf as an extension of their lifestyle. The campaign is shot across unconventional backdrops — city simulators, desert ranges, minimalist driving bays — with cinematic visuals blending precision and self-expression. The P790 Irons become a metaphor for evolution: forged for those who merge mastery with individuality. The result is a narrative that celebrates golf not as a tradition to protect, but as a culture to reinvent.
